question: In humans, are higher plasma L-carnitine levels, particularly when accompanied by elevated TMAO, associated with a lower incidence of cardiovascular events? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: We demonstrate here that metabolism by intestinal microbiota of dietary L-carnitine, a trimethylamine abundant in red meat, also produces TMAO and accelerates atherosclerosis in mice.
content.source_2: Chronic dietary L-carnitine supplementation in mice altered cecal microbial composition, markedly enhanced synthesis of TMA and TMAO, and increased atherosclerosis, but this did not occur if intestinal microbiota was concurrently suppressed.
content.source_3: In a prospective human cohort, higher fasting plasma L-carnitine in the context of elevated TMAO was associated with a lower incidence of major adverse cardiovascular events over follow-up, after multivariable adjustment.
content.source_4: Long-term L-carnitine supplementation reduced cecal TMA and TMAO generation and attenuated atherosclerotic lesion development in mice, even after withdrawal of microbiota suppression.
